Line: I feel like somebody should’ve warned me about how dangerous delivering pizzas could be.
The pay's good! What could go wrong Omar?
Notes: Should Fade in and Fade out

Line: Little did I know, death would be delivered to ME in the most tomatoey way possible.
Ugh…my head.
I don't think I've ever had a headache this bad before. It feels like my brain was tossed into a blender with one too many nails and dumped back into my head after a good five-minute shake.
SNIFF SNIFF
What is that smell?
IS THAT ME?
Duh. Who else could it be, silly?
Who's there?
I bolt to my feet and look around, but I don’t see anyone.
Hellooooooo darling~!
Ooky, kooky, and oh so fabulous.
As she winks, a puff of smoke shaped like a skull rises from her pipe.
Think of me as your distant auntie. It keeps a few centuries off of me, but call me your Spooky Grimmother. It’s all the same to me.
The woman’s expression contorts to one of annoyance. She takes a puff from her pipe and lets out a sigh filled with exhaustion.
And they say the dead aren’t loud…
What? H-how’d you do that?
So, Spooky Grimmother, which side of the family are you from?
She opens her mouth to answer but stops as if she’s in a freeze frame.
You know, I can’t even remember at this point. I’ve helped pass on so many of the family you’re all starting to blur together.
She pinches my cheeks and something that looks like dust clings to her fingertips. She cringes at the sight and dusts her hand on her dress.
Sorry, hun. I’ve spent too much time in the Underworld. I haven’t had a case like yours in ages.
The Underworld is real?!
Wrong question, hun. Have you seen your reflection yet?
No. Should I? Is something wrong?!
I’m guessing you don’t recognize the smell of decay on yourself either, huh?
She wiggles her finger and a hand mirror pops into her palm.
She holds it up to where I can see it. Something that could’ve been me stares back from the mirror, startling me, and makes me trip over my own feet to get away from it.
I put my hand over my heart to catch my breath but all I feel is a cold. No pulse. I couldn’t even feel my lungs expand. I wasn’t breathing.
Honey, you’re a zombie.
This time I didn't scream. I stare into the mirror and trace the shape of my cheeks. With one of my nails, I scratch at my face to see if I could feel anything. There wasn’t even an ache.
My jaw fell to the floor. Literally.
What the hell is going on?
A chance to get closure.
She snaps her finger and my jaw floats up before reattaching to my head.
If you haven’t connected the dots yet, you very much did not die from natural causes.
You were killed.
So, I did what any good Grimmother would do and brought you back.
The rotting teeth and bones peeking out from your skin are just a minor side effect.

Shortened Line 2: Bring me back to life all the way!

Line: So...
This is it for me? I’m just stuck as a zombie forever?

My chin follows my eyes as I stare down at my hands. The skin around my skull droops and weighs down my skull. Spooky Grimmother cups my face with her hands before my head could fall onto the ground and looks me dead in the eyes.
H-Hey! Don’t act like that. Zombification isn’t all bad. Most people don’t get the chance to find out who whacked them, but you do!
No godchild of mine is going to waste an opportunity like this by acting like a bag of bones.
Why would you bring me back as a zombie? I want to be normal!
That’s out of my jurisdiction sweetheart. I’m your Spooky Grimmother. Not your defy-life-and-death mother.
An incomplete revival is the best I can do.
Can’t you do it again? Like reheating pizza pockets?
No I-- how is the reintroduction of your soul back into your body anything like reheating pizza pockets?
It’s like when you bite into one right after taking it out the microwave, but then you taste how cold it is in the middle.
Obviously you can’t just keep eating it if it’s still a little frozen, so you just throw them back into the--
Alright, alright, we’re getting off track.
I’m putting my foot down, hun. I can’t do it again. Your soul wouldn’t survive the process and your body would look more like worm food than it already does.
I groan.
Anyway, you’re only a zombie and, if you want to find out who killed you, you’re going to stay as a zombie.
Well, how much time do I have to find my killer?
Just until Halloween ends. Sooo… we’re looking at around three days. Starting now.
I’m supposed to find a killer in THREE days? I don’t even remember what happened before I died!
Well, I wouldn’t have brought you back if it was impossible.
Where do I even start?
Bubbles of anxiety surge up from my stomach and into my shaky hands. Even though my body didn’t need it, I took in a deep breath to steady my hands and my nerves.
Well, you could start by looking down.
Down? What?
A 13th Pizza box lies turned over next to my feet. Whoever had ordered it must have wanted a slasher special because of all the pepperonis. The dent on it looks suspiciously like the back of my head.

A blanket lies on the ground next to my car. I must’ve thrown it off after I got up. Holding it in my hands, it’s really comfortable. Like, really comfy. On top of the handmade vibe it has going on, it’s honestly super charming.
Towards the bottom of the blanket, I run my fingers over an embroidered “L.C”.
L.C, huh? These must be the initials of whoever sewed the blanket.
Ooh! See! It hasn’t even been a full day and you already got your first clue! Good job, hun!
Thanks Spooky G, but one clue doesn’t feel like enough for me to go on at the moment though.
Tucking the blanket into my arms, I open the driver’s side door to my car. It’s a good thing I never lock the doors when I’m doing deliveries.

A smile bursts onto my face when I see the keys are still in the ignition. Resting the blanket on the passenger seat, I turn the keys until the engine roars to life and then settles into it’s usual sputtering while it's parked.
The best move for me right now would probably be to go back to work.
Oh sure, waste your second chance at life throwing dough in the air. Every young man’s death wish come true.
Have a little more faith, Spooky G. It wouldn’t make sense for me to spend all day knocking on apartment doors and asking people if they killed me. I gotta work smarter, not harder.

I figure my manager must keep receipts of any orders made online just in case we get complaints or mess up the pizzas. If I can compare the day I was killed with the last order I delivered then I’ll also have the address of the person who killed me.
Well look at you go, Sherlock.
I shrug but I can’t hide the pride in my smile. This is gonna be easy!
Or at least it would be if Spooky Grimmother wasn’t stopping me from closing the driver’s door.
Ah, ah, ah! Hold on. I don’t want you going off on your little adventure without me telling you about Rigor Mortis.
Rigor Mortis? Didn’t that already happen?
Not exactly, my little numbskull.
You’re about halfway between a regular human and a brain-crazed cannibalistic corpse, and the only thing keeping you from going full zombie is your body.

In other words, hun, your body has a mind of its own now. If you over-exert it by running a marathon, trying to lift up a car, or anything else along those lines then your body is going to call it quits and kick out your soul.

So be careful these next three days. If you push your body too hard then you won’t even make it to Halloween. Without your soul, your body is going to start hunting for brains and the zombie apocalypse isn’t scheduled for another century.
I act like I’m taking a deep breath and then sigh before resting my head against the steering wheel.
W-well what about my soul? If my body goes through rigor mortis 2.0 then my soul just gets kicked out and I’ll pass on like you said, right?
She takes a long drag from her pipe before shaking her head.
Let’s just say… you’re not passing on anywhere without finishing your business.
You can tell how far along you are by how hard it’ll be for you to move. It’s your body’s way of telling you to ease up.
I nod at her and then towards the driver’s door.
You gonna let me go now, or is there more to tell about this seemingly shit second chance at life you’ve given me?
Don’t get smart with me, boy. Now go on and find the unlucky punk who gets to have a zombie chasing them down.

She moves out of the way so I can close the driver’s door. As I check the rearview mirror, I catch a glimpse of my new zombified appearance again. I smiled when I realized I hadn’t gasped and pulled off from the parking lot towards my job: The 13th Pizza

As soon as I step through the double doors, a groan slips through my cracked lips and my shoulders slump as if my life had been snatched a second time. Ah, The 13th Pizza never makes me regret staying away.

This grease trap is the infamous 13th attempt at a pizzeria by the owner, Charles Ray Lee. The guy had bad luck with running food establishments, but he wouldn’t let his pie-filled dream die. A real shame for everyone he hired.
A high-pitched voice tinged with voice cracks breaks the humming of the A/C Charles didn’t fix.
Oh my God! Omar!?

Before I can whip my head towards the counter, a pair of arms wrap tightly around my shoulders and pull me into a bear hug. My arms nearly pop out of their sockets along with my eyes before Iggy, my shift partner, lets me go and punches my chest.

Where have you been?! You don’t call in sick to the boss, you don’t even send a text to me, and then you make me look like an asshole for calling your phone five times everyday when even your parents didn’t know where you are!
How’re you just going to ghost everyone for three weeks?!
Three weeks?! I’ve been gone for three weeks?!
Duh! Did you lose track of time while you were on your ghost vacation?! You owe me big time! And then you have the audacity to walk in here like a…
He sniffs the air and twitches his nose to hold back his disgust.
Dude, you’re smelling a little ripe. I can give you some of the deodorant in my bag, but I want an answer first. What happened?
I wrap my arms around his neck and shove his nose closer to my armpits so he can get a good whiff of me. We both laugh it off as he shoves me away and stare at each other as we wear the same smile.
I missed you too, Ig. Really appreciate the warm welcome.
Yeah, yeah, yeah. Stop dodging the question though, man.
I’m not dodging, I’m not dodging. I’m still trying to figure out what happened to me. The last few weeks are kind of a blur, and definitely not in a fun way.
That’s some hangover, man. If you drank as much as I thought, I’m surprised you’re still standing. Did something happen with your parents? You need to crash with me again?
Oh no, I’m good. I’m just trying to piece some things together.
I really appreciate you covering for me, man. I don’t know how you did it, but I-
Iggy shakes his head to cut me off and raises his hand. Like we’d done probably a million times before, I give him a high five and finish our signature handshake with a fist bump.
Don’t even worry about it. When you didn’t show up for your shift, I volunteered to cover for you until you came back before Charles could even write up the new schedule.
You still owe me, though.
Let me know soon so I won’t forget. I don’t need you holding this over my head.
Our laughs fill the restaurant as we make our way behind the register.
It was like I’d never left.
Well…
Basically, I died and got brought back to life by a spooky, grim godmother I never knew I had. I’m guessing that I died three weeks ago while I was on my shift, but I don’t remember who did it.

My Spooky Grimmother says that I only have until Halloween night to figure out who killed me or else I’m gonna be stuck as a ghost and my body will start the zombie apocalypse that’s due sometime in the 23rd century.
He stares at me with his hands holding onto something in his pockets. I scratch my hair to distract myself from the silence and his eyes.
That’s pretty much everything I know. I came back here to see if I could get any clues about what happened to me.
He stomps behind the counter.
Is it so hard for you to tell me the truth?!
Ig, I am telling you the truth.
Whatever, man.
Iggy, please. You’ve got to believe me.
You said I’ve been gone for three weeks right? I don’t remember anything from that time! The last thing I remember is saying goodbye to you and Ms. Gin before I drove off to drop off the deliveries.
I fall to my knees in front of the counter and press my forehead against the dust-covered floor.
Iggy, I’m begging you! I need you to believe me on this! I’m on my knees, man!
Iggy crosses his arms and grumbles. I can see the thoughts churning in his head, but whether he’ll believe me is still a coin toss.
Ugh.
He sighs into a relaxed smirk.
I don’t know if I believe you, but I’ll play along cuz we’re bros. Just remember you owe me.
Thank you, thank you, thank you!
I tackled him with the tightest hug I could muster until I felt my arm start to pop out of place. Iggy shoved me off so he must not have noticed.
I know, I know, I’m pretty awesome. Come on.
I follow him behind the register with a dumb grin on my face. It was like I’d never left.
Alright, where’s our lovely manager?
Oh, Rudy called in sick today.
The one day I actually want to see his face and he’s gone. Just my luck…
A kind-hearted old lady with a smile on her face and quarters jingling in her pocket walks up to the counter. I’m already smiling before I realize who it is.
Ms. Gin! How’s my favorite customer?
Her laugh is like a warm pie during Christmas.
Omar! I thought you quit and ran for the hills. It’s been ages since I’ve seen you!
I chuckle awkwardly. It doesn’t seem like a good idea to tell her I’ve just been dead for three weeks.
Just been feeling a bit under the weather. I bounce back pretty easy, ma’am!
I hope so dear. You look a few steps from death still! Maybe another few days off would have done you some extra good.
Thanks for the concern, ma’am. Trust me, I’ll be fine!
I hope at least.
Ms. Gin stares into my face the way only a mother could give when she’s looking to see if there is anything wrong with you.
Uh… You’re kind of freaking me out, Ms. Gin.
Sorry, Omar. I just feel like something is different about you. Are you doing something different with your hair?
OOOOOOH!!!
She’s on your head, Mar-Mar.
Oh, hush. I’m still me and that’s all that matters.
You came here for the usual, Ms. G?
Just as I slide her over an empty small cup the eighty-five cents in her pocket are already on the counter.
Thank you, dear. You know when you told me you were heading over to The Woodsboro Apartments I thought you’d never come back.
My eyes shoot up from the cash register as I shove it closed.
The Woodsboro Apartments? The place where security never sleeps?
Something like that. It's quite a stuffy-looking place to me. You were handling deliveries there if my memory serves me right.
Oh! Hey, since you’re not dead in a ditch somewhere that reminds me. You’re on schedule tonight, dude.
Of course, I am…
It was hard to report to work as usual as if I’m not a zombie. There was something very normal about the mundanity of the shift. I get a pizza, I deliver, I pray I get a tip, and repeat.
The next few hours had me looking at the rest of my day as a stopwatch, and I was counting down the minutes until I could take my break and head over to Woodsboro Apartments.

I had told Iggy that I’d be taking a break at my usual spot before I left, and, as usual, he handed me a 10-inch slasher special pizza. They’re sweet. It’s usually a pizza I’d get to eat on break if I was in the mood for one.
I open the pizza box to get a good whiff of the saucy goodness I’m usually happy to breathe in.
Nothing.
Even the smell of greasy cheap pizza didn’t stir me. If I had an appetite for anything it's not for pizza anymore.

The next few hours had me looking at the rest of my day as a stopwatch, and I was counting down the minutes until I could take my break and head over to Woodsboro Apartments. My complimentary pizza still rested on the back seat of my car as I pulled up to the gate.
I reach into the backseat and grab the mystery blanket I woke up with. Somehow it still feels rather cozy.
Alright, back here again…
Well, I could’ve told you that much dear.
Ah!
I jump out of my skin and let out a harsh breath through my nose to calm myself down.
Please stop doing that-- sparkle thing!
I’m sorry, next time I’ll make sure I poof in a glorious display of hellfire and the screams of the damned.
I narrow my eyes at her as sarcasm drips from her voice. My attention moves toward the apartment registry.

Alright, Ms. Gin said this was the last place I was heading to make a delivery. I’m betting the killer lives in this apartment complex. Since I only have this blanket, I might as well make it worth it.

Maybe the initials on the blanket are the same as someone on the registry. If I find the right person then I can just say I’m returning the blanket and they’ll let me in. Best case scenario they can tell me about how I died.
I don’t know, I’d tell you to leave it downstairs if someone tried to do that for me.
I’m ignoring you now.
I huff as I press the down arrow until I make it towards the L names.
Only two L.C.’s? L. Coner and L. Cloverfield. I’ll have to make a guess here.
A feminine sing-songy voice comes through the intercom’s static.
Hello~
Uh, hi! I’m Omar. I’m with The 13th Pizza. I think I have your blanket. It’s blue and it has your initials on it.
Oh, my blanket! Explains why you were sleeping next to the pizza delivery car.
Her voice, and the laugh that followed it, tickle my heart and guide a laugh of my own from underneath my focus.
I uh… Yeah, I really appreciated it. I appreciate it so much that I wanted to come by and give it back to you. Ha ha…
Oh, that’s super nice of you! As long as you’re not some murder hobo with a knife I guess I can accept that as you actually wanting to buzz you in.
Come on through. I’m on the second floor of apartment 418.
Like gravel sliding down a chalkboard, a voice pushes past the static.
What do you want?
Um… I want to return a blanket?
I ain’t got no blanket.
Well, sir, I have a blanket here that has the initials L.C. on it and I’m just trying to return it.
I’m not interested in whatever you’re selling! You already got my social security number!
Sir, I’m just trying to return--
No answer. I shift uncomfortably.
…Hello?
Hope he gets that social security problem fixed. I pray the other person happened to have left a blanket out in a parking lot somewhere.

After the intercom buzzes, the gears in the gate whirl, and eventually open enough for me to pass through, I end up finding her apartment once I scale the stairs to the second floor. With my pizza in one hand and the blanket in the other, I give the door a few soft knocks.
Notes: Redo line in post jam update

Line: Ms. Coner? It’s Omar with The 13th Pizza.
Coming!
The apartment door swings wide open and I finally put a face to the most memorable voice I’d ever heard.
Nice to finally see you again, Omar.
Also, you can just call me Leah.
Pleasure to finally meet you. Er, sorry if I’m interrupting your evening.
Oh, it's no problem. This is the most excitement I’ve had in weeks. I’ve been having a zombie movie marathon for myself before Halloween.
Talk about irony…
Oh, that’s really neat. What’s your favorite zombie movie?
Definitely Plane to Daegu.
Oh, good taste.
We stand there for a moment, smiling in the silence of a first impression, before I break it like an idiot by shoving her blanket towards her.
Oh, I almost forgot about that. Hehe!
I wouldn’t let myself go unless you got it back. It’s a really cool blanket by the way. It was really nice waking up to it.
I had knitted it myself! Anything I make always has my initials on it somewhere in case I lose it.

I get comfortable by leaning against the doorframe as Leah reaches behind her door to show me more things she’s made by hand. Gloves, sweaters, and even some skull caps come and go from view before she shrugs.
With the little time I do have on my hands, I like to make the most of it.
So why’d you waste your time putting a blanket over a stranger like me?
I wouldn’t call it a waste at all. I saw somebody who looked cold so I gave them a way to warm up. Who better to give a blanket to than a sleeping homeless guy?
Not me looking homeless…
Oh! I’m sorry I didn’t mean-- it’s just I don’t know many people who just decide to fall asleep next to their car. What were you doing asleep anyway?
I’m actually trying to figure that out. The past three weeks have been kind of a blur. I’ve been trying to retrace my steps all day.
You wouldn’t happen to remember somebody from The 13th Pizza delivering here around that time would you?
Well, I know the people above me always order pizza from you guys.
Come to think of it, there was a pretty bad argument between a delivery guy and one of the tenants up there. I didn’t see who since it wasn’t any of my business, you know?
I nodded along as my eyes looked down, lingering on the pizza in my hand.
Totally understand. If I was in your shoes around that time, I would’ve done the same thing. Hey, I was wondering, did you maybe want this-
From my pocket, the stopwatch on my phone plays the opening notes of Danse Macabre.
Oh crap, my break is almost over!
An idea pops into my head. I feel as if I have to thank her for her help in some way.
Uh, who doesn’t?
I pull out the pizza from the bag it was nestled in.
Here, it's a 10-inch slasher special pizza.
Oh, but I didn’t order--!
Without a second thought, I shove the pizza box into Leah’s hands and dashed to the stairs.
Thanks for your help, Leah! I’ll talk to you later! Enjoy the pizza! The cheese is also under the sauce!
Oh, okay! Let’s hang out sometimes! I’m free next Friday!
I’d like that a lot!
Sorry, Leah! I gotta go! It was nice meeting you!
Nice meeting you too! Glad I could help!
I bolt for the stairs and instinctively toss the pizza I had in hand. Any other time I probably would have thought of that as a waste, but now isn’t the time for thinking.

My hands had already grabbed onto the railing before my feet could touch the stairs. Bad reviews were something I could deal with, but I wouldn’t live to even SEE Halloween night if Iggy had to deal with me being late again.

I was in the car and driving out of Woodsboro before I knew it. One day down, two more to go, and I’m right on track to finding my killer! I’d give myself a high-five if they weren’t on the steering wheel.

I ended up sleeping in my car last night and just drove back to work as soon as I woke up. Figured it was better to not explain my new living situation to my parents and tell them about Spooky Grimmother.
Iggy seemed more at ease since I was back to take some of the workload off of him. I didn’t have the heart to tell him that after tomorrow he probably wouldn’t see me again.
The fear that came with the thought only motivated me to find the killer more. No use curling up into a ball like a baby.
So, here I am. Inside my car, parked inside The Woodsboro Apartments, and having Spooky Grimmother smoke over my shoulder. My new and perfectly normal life for the next couple of hours.
Quit smoking so close to me. I don’t like the smell of whatever it is you’ve got in that pipe, and I’d rather the customers not have their pizza smell like smoke.
You know you don’t have to breathe anymore, right?
I don’t need to breathe anymore, but other people still do!
Besides, It reminds me that I’m still alive and helps me focus. I’m gonna need it to make the most of today. Tomorrow’s my last chance.
Clever boy. So what is your plan? Focus really hard on your killer and scare them with your breathing techniques?
My head turns to glare at her.
No… I’m making the most of another opportunity. I’ve got another delivery in this place.
Seems like they can’t get enough of The 13th Pizza. Is the delivery close to that new girl’s place? You two seemed to hit it off. What was her name again?
Leah.
I surprised myself with just how fast I’d said her name and even more so that Spooky Grimmother didn’t call me out on it. She just nods her head and looks at the building we’re in front of.
So, you’re just going to use your break and knock on every door up there until the killer comes out?
Hell no. That would take half of my break and wouldn’t leave me any time for questions. I need to pick two doors and get whoever is in them to talk me through what they remember that night.
And if they don’t remember anything?
Then I’m gonna pray that the walk up those stairs jog my memory. I know it’s not a lot SG, but it’s all I’ve got without any help.
I tilted my neck and waved in her general, magical direction. A puff of smoke was her initial response as she blew it right above my head.
You know as much as I do, hun. Besides, I’m all spent from bringing you back.
Besides if you want a tip, I suggest you fix your neck before you talk to anyone outside this car.

As my eyes drifted down, the straining of my skin to not tear around my neck was obvious along with the fact that it was twisted a hundred-eighty degrees. I didn’t even flinch as I held my face and righted myself, stretching a bit to make sure I’d gotten it back into place properly.
Good boy.
Now go on out there and do some detective work. I’m rooting for ya!

And just like that, she was gone. Even though she pulled at my nerves, I already missed her. As the only person who really understood what was happening to me, she made doing what I had to actually feel worth something.

I wish I felt the same about these damn stairs. Besides just the physical work, memories of my past crept back into my head like a couple of slugs. Flashes of my feet running down these same stairs sped past my focus along with a pair of distorted voices that felt familiar.

Notes: Focus on Voices = Takes less from meter Ignore the Voices = Takes more from the Meter

Line: Still ascending the stairs, I zeroed in on the voices and they immediately became clear. There weren’t two voices. Only one and it was like something straight out of a nightmare. A very real nightmare that every retail or food service worker dreads.
Excuse me?! EXCUSE ME?! Who do you think you’re talking to?! I am not one of your pizza grease-covered coworkers, okay?! I will not allow myself to be degraded because you delivered the wrong order!
Notes: This is Akilla's voice! (Potentially get a silhouette for her so this might be edited)

Line: The toppings are not how they looked in the photo I saw! How hard is it to follow directions?! I’m sure you guys don’t cook all those pizzas from memory?! You do? No wonder it’s atrocious.
Notes: This is Akilla's voice! (Potentially get a silhouette for her so this might be edited)

Line: No, don’t take it now! You already delivered it. Just give me a refund already. It’s the least you can do.
Notes: This is Akilla's voice! (Potentially get a silhouette for her so this might be edited)

Line: HOW DARE YOU?!
Notes: This is Akilla's voice! (Potentially get a silhouette for her so this might be edited)

Line: Memories of the voice retreated from my mind as I reached the third floor, and I was left shaking my head to try to get the high-pitched screech of that person out of my head. It was a woman definitely and one with a serious attitude.

Once I had recomposed myself, the discomfort of that woman’s voice has been replaced with a teeth-gritting anger. That was definitely what my killer sounded like and for a split second, I wished I didn’t.

I shut my eyes and drown out the voices with the thumping of my heels against the stairs. I feel myself grip harder onto the railing. I muster everything in my power to push back against the bubbling feeling of some kind of uneasy familiarity.
Whatever that was about wasn’t something I wanted to touch just yet. I’ll leave the spooky stuff to my Grimmother.
I step away from the railing and I roughly stop in my tracks. I look down and notice my hand is still gripping the railing. I move my hand, but my grip doesn’t lessen.
With my other hand, I pry my right hand off from the railing. I stretch my fingers in an attempt to see how they’re moving. They seem fine.
Gotta be nerves…
After a few more strides toward the doors, which I guessed were right above Leah’s, I looked at the two doors in front of me.

The first door, Apartment #518, doesn’t have anything too special about it. A pretty generic welcome mat, a fake potted plant, and a skeletal wreath hanging from the door, most likely only there for the holidays.
The second door, Apartment #519 just had a welcome mat with an axolotl holding its middle fingers up.
Classy.
The first door held my attention and received my first knock.
Oh! uh, my name’s Omar and I deliver pizzas from The 13th Pizza.
A distant voice, sounding about as tired as I felt, echoed from behind the door.
I’m sorry. I didn’t order any pizza.
Er, I understand that. I’m actually following up on an incident that happened about three weeks ago. Would you know anything about that?
Three weeks ago? Hm…
Gimme a second.
A series of clicks and clacks come from the door as latches and locks are undone. When the door finally creaked open, the person standing in the unlit apartment looked more like a zombie than I did.
Name’s Edie. Edie Frueger. Sorry if I look like I just crawled out of a coffin, I don’t really get much sleep around here.
You’re totally fine uh… Sorry, I’m not really sure to say ma’am or sir. What’s your preference?
Neither. Call me a ghoul.
They laughed at themselves. I laughed along so they wouldn’t have to deal with the awkward silence.
Could I just stick to calling you Edie? I’m Omar by the way.
They nodded and scratched their cheek while they looked lost in thought.
I’m trying to remember…
There was definitely a little scuffle that happened across the hall a while ago. We love The 13th Pizza on this floor, but some of us forget that you guys aren’t just workers who do whatever we say.

I’d never heard anybody get so upset over a wrong order. The Slasher Special is one of my personal favorites so just hearing them screaming their head off and demanding a refund was damn near ridiculous.

I can barely get any sleep these days so I’m usually up most nights, but even if I could sleep I don’t even think I’d be able to sleep through the screeching from that night. It sounded like they even chased the guy down the hall.
Sounded like a bat out of hell, I was honestly scared to open the door to even take a look.
It was Akilla, Edie.
Both Edie and I turned our attention to Apartment #519. A tall and looming figure leans against the doorframe brandishing a knife with-- is that blood?
Even without opening your door I’m sure she wouldn’t be a hard guess for anyone.
Oh hey Mason. You meal prepping again?
The man’s eyes widen as he catches my rather alarmed expression.
Crap, wait my bad. I was chopping fruits.
Mason leans back inside and I hear the metal clack of a knife hitting a sink.
I couldn’t help but be a lil’ nosy. Akilla was the one making a scene on the floor those few weeks back.
Edie facepalmed themselves as everything seemed to click in their head.
Yeah, yeah, yeah! The prime time Karen.
I forget her name so I won’t have to remember all the shit she’s pulled.
She’s a real piece of work. I had my headphones in as soon as I heard her starting to raise her voice. Not the first time she’s gotten pissy about a wrong order.
And sometimes they’re not even wrong! She just wants a free pizza.
And where is she?

I dug my nails into my palms to keep myself distracted from the slow tug of my anger. Both Edie and Mason point toward the door directly behind me. I tuned out the rest of their conversation as I scoped out and shuffled towards the door.
Finally, I got you now!
Hello! The 13th Pizza!
Silence. A conscious numbing, rage-stoking silence that either comes from someone not being home or wanting to avoid the ass whoopin’ they had earned.
Can’t resist any door with a doormat as cool as this one.
I give the door a careful knock. I hear shuffling from the inside and a deep voice calls out.
Who is it?
Oh, uh hey. I’m Omar and I’m from The 13th Pizza.
Silence follows.
I didn’t order anything. I told Kyle to stop sending pizzas to my door as a prank--
Oh, no. I’m not delivering anything. Just trying to ask some questions about an incident from three weeks back.
The deep voice hums as if it’s thinking to itself.
It’s all good I don’t mean to bother you or anything--
The door clicks and opens and a looming figure steps out from the apartment, he looks down at me brandishing a knife covered in a red blood-like substance.
About three weeks ago, you said?
Uh, your…
The man raises his eyebrow
Oh crap. Hold on.
He steps back inside. The clack of metal against metal rings out as if he'd placed something down.
The name’s Mason. What were you needing again?

I relax as I watch the man attempt to rub at the cherry stains on his shirt and hands to no avail. He loses all the prior intimidation, as I see him for what he truly is. A gym bro trying his hand at meal-prepping something other than plain chicken.
There was a delivery here three weeks ago that seemed to have an incident. Would you know anything about that?
Mason chuckles.
Oh man, that was the most noise I’ve heard on this floor in months.
The leasing office actually gives out coupons to The 13th Pizza so it's pretty popular here. It’s common to see you guys here. I think I’ve even seen your face before.
But anyways, in the middle of my reps, I just hear screeching and this chick’s going IN on some poor dude outside about some wrong order.
I mean, I’m more of a Calzone kind of guy, but sheesh. It’s never that serious. I’m sure the order wasn’t even wrong and she was just looking for an extra discount.
Do you have a name? Or know which door?
You’re usually a lot quicker when it comes to ragging on Akilla.
I whip my head to see a person who looks just as tired as me.
Sorry Edie. Did you get enough beauty sleep tonight?
Their eyes narrow at Mason.
Shut up.
Mason snorts.
Sorry.
Mason turns his attention back to me.
Edie is right. I just hate saying her name. I feel like if I invoke her then she’ll show up on my coffee table and ask to see my manager or something.
Mason points to a door across from him. Edie seems equally annoyed by the memory.
I dug my nails into my palms to keep myself distracted from the slow tug of my anger. I tuned out the rest of their conversation as I scoped out and shuffled towards the door.
Gotchu, bitch.
Silence. A conscious numbing, rage-stoking silence that either comes from someone not being home or wanting to avoid the ass whoopin’ they had earned.

Raising my hand towards the door, I felt every nerve in my body fire at once before I could even touch it. In that instance, I was a passenger in my own body. I saw myself bury my fingers into the doorframe. The door ripped out of the hinges as if it were nothing.
I open my mouth to speak, but my jaw feels tight. It finally opens but I groan and slur. I can only stare in horror as a passenger in my own body.
Sh-shit!?!
My feet, now moving less organized, led me into the apartment as my nose sniffed the air for the scent of the iron within a beating heart. I only feel fear. My body feels as if it is not my own.
The sound of doors opening in the hallway snaps me back as I feel sensation come back to my body.
What’s going on in here!?
W-Wait. I know this looks bad. I-It fell off the hinges when I knocked! I swear!
The man takes out his phone.
The door is torn to shreds!? Do you think I’m stupid?
My heart drops. The man grabs my shoulder with his phone in his other hand.
No, no, no… This is not how this is supposed to go!
I didn’t--
More doors open. I can’t stick around here. I break away from the man and bolt out of the room.
Accusations and questions bubble out of the man. I can’t be caught up here.
I can’t.
I push past the man, every single undead atom in my body screams in unison.
I see Mason and Edie with their mouths agape. Mason attempts to grab for my arm but I juke the towering man just in time to make a beeline for the staircase.
Hey! What are you doing!?
I will my body to move, my body feels like cinderblocks tied to my feet. Left, right, left, right. I repeat it over and over as if it is a mantra in attempt to convince my body to keep moving.
The heavy thumps from above me follow. It might as well could be an entire army coming after me.
Left, right, left, right--
My left leg bends and I stumble from the last few steps. A horrific CRACK resounds and I come tumbling down.
Come on, come on!
I stand and come crashing back down, I whip my head to see it broke off from my knee. The footsteps grow louder.
Come on, come on!
I push myself up from the ground in an attempt to hop away with my leg discarded on the step.
Where do you expect to go with just one leg!?
Spooky Grimmother scoots over my leg with her heel and helps me jam it back into place. My leg gains feeling once again as I jump upright.
I’ve been putting back on limbs ever since I woke up from death anyway!
I haul myself up and grab for my leg discarded on the step and jam it back into place. It does exactly what I expect it to as I feel I am able to move it again.
The footsteps grow louder.
Crap, crap, crap!
I throw myself up and make way for the door.
I slam through the door of the apartment building and greet the fresh night air, delivery car in sight. I’m almost home free.

I ran away as best as I could. Moving felt like moving through butter instead of the fluidity I’d gotten used to. My joints scream to stay and search for Akilla, but they end up going forward because my brain was more imposing. At least for the moment.

Once back in the car, I drive right out of the apartments without even buckling myself up. My vision is blurring, my adrenaline waning, and my body is stiffening and locking up so much it feels like even a twitch from me will break my skin like a fortune cookie.
Sp-Spooky… Gri-Grimmother…
She appears, floating beside me in the passenger’s seat. Her smile fades into horror at the sight of me, but plummets into motherly annoyance after the initial shock.
You numbskull! I told you! I warned you about what would happen and, of course, you didn’t listen to me! Hold still! I gotta fix everything...
With a wave of her pipe, a smoke ring swirls about the size of a choker around my neck and loosens up my body just enough for me to move without worry. A temporary solution to my growing problems.
Great hells, you’re even worse than I thought...
I found out who the killer was. I busted down her door but she wasn’t home. I’m… I’m not sure I’m all the way here.
Well if that isn’t a stressful situation then I don’t know what is. At least you know who she is, but don’t be so reckless next time. Rigor mortis is not a joke, Omar.
You’re close to the end, hun. Time is almost up for you, your Rigor Mortis has jumped higher in one day than I’ve ever seen in my existence, but at least you know exactly where the killer is.
Take a breath, honey. Get some sleep.
Spooky Grimmother catches herself. Even she seems to forget I don’t need sleep anymore.
Just…take some time to relax at least.

For a second, I question whether it was a good idea for me to sit here with my thoughts. After everything that's happened a break feels like the last thing I need but, with the ring of smoke around me thickening into a full on cloud and my car quickly turning into a hotbox, I knew it was a good idea.
For the first time since this waking nightmare had started my eyes got heavy and, after that first yawn, I fell into the best sleep of my life.
Goodnight, darling Omar.
Whoa!
I open my eyes with a start and scan around the car.
Happy Halloween Omar.
Spooky Grimmother lounges in my passenger seat as she puffs out skull-shaped smoke.
W-What time is it!? Why didn’t you wake me up?
You’re dead. What am I going to do? I couldn’t wake you up even if I tried. You’re losing your grip on your body, Omar!
I roll my eyes, grab my seatbelt, and check my phone.
Holy crap, there’s barely any time left!
I hit the gas as I make my way back to The Woodsboro Apartments.
I’ve got about twelve hours to have a face-to-face with Akilla before my body kicks me out and goes on a zombie-style buffet. I don’t have any time to waste.
I pull up to the dreaded gate, get out of my car, and start kicking my tires.
Stupid, sleep-deprived, rusty hinges havin’, no oil check lookin’, rusty gold chain colored gate! I hate you!
I give my tires a few more good kicks before I take a deep breath to calm myself down.
Okay, chill Omar. Let’s figure this out. Don’t let a dumb gate stop you.
My fingers glided over the intercom registry until I reached Leah’s name. One click and buzz later, her voice comes through.
Hello?
Hey Leah, it’s Omar. Could you let me in?

Well, I was planning to order pizza anyway, but I’m not sure if that’s a good idea. The apartment watch is saying that we shouldn’t be letting in any more pizza delivery guys after what happened last night.
I sucked in my teeth and looked away from the intercom.
You heard about that huh?
Everyone’s heard about it. I figured it might’ve been you, but what made you think it was okay to kick down that lady's door, dude?

It’s a lot for me to get into but basically she took something away from me for getting her order wrong. She demanded I give her a refund AND keep the pizza which I obviously couldn’t do so now I JUST want to talk.
She’s silent on the other end. I feel my heart drop as I feel as if she could have just left. I move in closer to the intercom, desperation takes over.
Leah, please. I’ve been going through absolute hell for the last few days.
I just wanna put an end to…whatever this is.
…Okay. I know we don’t know each other that well, but just be careful. Alright?
The intercom buzzes against and the gears grind together as they pull the gate apart. I had driven through before it was even fully open.
I punch the side of my steering wheel in annoyance. I am NOT dealing with this gate right now.
I tighten my seatbelt, grit my teeth, and slam my foot on the gas.

Many things happen at once. My airbag goes off as shattered glass send a thousand cuts along my clothes and skin. An eye pops out, but I push it back in just as quickly. I've never been more happy to be dead already.
I peel away at the bent car door and leave the vehicle.
The clock is ticking. I might as well do what I’ve always done and make the most of it. The car door damn near breaks apart as I slam it and rush up to the gate to scale it.

My legs have a mind of its own as I jump high enough to grab the top of the gate and haul myself over. The leg of my pants gets caught in the spikes at the top but I ignore it. It shreds my pants up but not enough for me to care.
I land on the ground and my knees tense up, I am reminded of Spooky Grimmother’s words, but I give them a wack to snap myself out of it.
I stomp down the hallway and find my way to Akilla’s door. She already seems to have her door back on the hinges.
I knock on the door of Akilla’s apartment and tap my foot as I wait.
OPEN UP!
I hear curses from the inside of the apartment. The door swings open, and memories flood back.
What the hell do you want?!
That shrieking voice was way too familiar.
It's you! You did this to me!
I didn’t DO anything to you? Who even are you?
Unbelievable.
I’m the guy who delivered your pizza.
She stares past me blankly, not even acting like she’s trying to remember.
I know every little delivery guy I meet, and none of them looked anything like you.
ARE YOU JOKING?!
Three weeks ago you ordered from The 13th Pizza, and you went off on me about a wrong order THAT WAS ALL YOUR FAULT!
Everyone knows the actual food doesn’t look like the advertisements!
That is untrue! I’ve had several orders that looked exactly like they did in the pictures, and I had every right to seek out the refund I rightfully deserved!
With every word that comes out of her mouth, my body and I grow closer to being on the same page. With every breath she takes my nails dig deeper into my palms until my bones taste air.
You chased me down two flights of stairs and threw the pizza you ordered at the back of my head!

I grab onto a section of the door frame and crush it without even breaking eye contact with her. My teeth grind themselves into fangs and somewhere in the decaying brain matter I have left I feel the urge to do the same thing to her skull, but I try my best to push it down.
The pizza you threw BROKE MY NECK!
You left me to die!
Oh, don’t be overdramatic. You were still moving a little bit.
SO, YOU DO REMEMBER, ME!
Well, I do now. I couldn’t forget such terrible customer service…
I tried contacting your manager but that young lady, Iggyanda or whatever, said that they were out. I’ve been a customer for NINETEEN years and I expected better customer service.
This woman is insufferable.
You’re wasting my time. Don’t you have wrong pizzas to deliver?
She moves to close her door and my zombified hand stops it.
She jumps back in horror as my congealed blood boils as I stomp into the apartment.
What the--?!
I watch the cogs turn in her head. Her nose crinkles as if she just caught a whiff of the worst odor she’s ever come across in her miserable life.
H-hey! Oscar, I'm sorry about the whole pizza thing. Let’s not get hasty here!
Is that what you want to hear? Get over it! Besides, if you really died then how are you even here?!
Special Delivery for Ms. Akilla!
I press my ear against the door as quietly as I can. And now I wait. This woman had me running all through these hallways and I’m not going to kick down her door again if she isn’t there.
The tension and anticipation were enough to unravel the sinews I have left. My toes curl into the soles of my shoes as my hands scratch off long strings of wood from the door.
Come on, come on! Just let me know you’re there you pizza throwin’, long neck havin’, turkey headed, lil’ gobble gobble lookin--
And then I hear it. The twisting of the top lock and the slight jiggle of a handle. My foot rises off the ground and smashes into the door before she could open it.
The door mutes her screams as I walk on top of the door and stare down at her. With the door pinning her down, here lies Akilla.
What the hell?! Who are you?! Get off of me now, and get out of my apartment!? I’m calling the pol-
Shut up!
Shut up?! You can’t talk to-
I press against the door now trapping Akilla. The familiar guttural gurgling bubbles up as I speak.
And now, neither can you! Funny, right?!
Her eyes scanned the room for something she could probably grab or at the least her phone so she could call somebody. It made my congealed blood boil.
Look at me!
As she does, I can see the cogs turning in her head. There’s the recognition. Finally.
That’s right.
It’s me. You know, the guy you left for dead? Broke my neck with a box of piping hot deep-dish pizza?
The same guy you chased down two flights of stairs while demanding a refund because the pizza didn’t match the advertisements you saw?!
Oh.
Oh? JUST OH?!

She wriggles from underneath the door in an attempt to get away. Drool from my uneven jaw falls on the back of the door. Her nose crinkles as if she just caught a whiff of the worst odor she’s ever come across in her miserable life.
She knows something is wrong, something unnatural.
Her face twists from disgust to annoyance. Her expression changes as if she tried really hard to look for a memory.
I’m sorry, Oscar!
She finally gathers up the rest of her strength to finally push the door, and in turn me, off of her.
She pants as she scoots away from me, unsure of the sight I am before her.
Is that what you want to hear? Get over it! Besides, if you really died then how are you even here?!
Please… Just leave me alone… You’ll never have to see me again and we can just go about living our lives…
My body lurches forward as I grab her head and dig my green tinged fingers into the side of her head.
The urge that has been bubbling deep inside of me has reaches its tipping point.
You really have the AUDACITY, the GALL, the ABSOLUTE NERVE to ask me to forgive you after YOU DON’T EVEN REMEMBER MY NAME!
My own voice causes me to pause. I feel my body trembling in anticipation, anticipation I fear to place.
LET GO! EVERYTHING IS YOUR FAULT! GET YOUR FILTHY MITTS OFF OF ME!
Akilla struggles in my grip. My mind feels cloudy. Akilla mutters other words in an attempt to convince me to let go of my vice grip. I tune her out.
For a wrong order, I was ripped away from everything. No more late night shifts with Iggy, no more slasher special pizza, I’m never going to go catch that movie with Leah.
I was just killed and left for dead covered in pizza sauce, and she gets to keep on living, happily, getting her refunds, never tipping.
All I get to be is dead.
Three weeks, and the only people that cared enough to even care about me were my best friend, a returning customer, and a complete stranger.
My eye twitches in its socket as my urge spurs me on again. I feel it from my belly, it wants to overtake me.
I haven’t felt pain since I woke, but this…this HURTS.
Would she feel pain? How do I get mine to stop?
Drool pools down from my face. Akilla’s so loud.
I could just…
Since coming back to life, me and my body always felt at odds with each other. But now, with Akilla still talking about how she’s the hero and the victim, something clicks.
I hunger.
I’M HUNGRY.

Y-you fell on purpose. I know you did! You must have done it so you could get out of giving me my refund. I’ve never seen anyone so committed to getting out of their responsibilities, but I hold everyone accountable, buddy!
No.
More!
TALKING!
I sink my teeth through the front of her skull.

All at once, I plunge my teeth into her skull. There wasn’t a scream or a struggle. Only muscle spasms from her body and the plopping of her blood on the floor as it drips from my chin. The ache in my belly satiates.
Oh… Oh God…
I knew you could do it, sweetie.
Spooky Grimmother, in all of her otherworldly style, floats behind me with her usual smirk. I can only imagine how I look from her perspective.

I try to say something to her, I want to gag from bits of gray matter rolling on my tongue, but I don’t. It’s revoltingly delicious, as it reminds me of the texture of spoiled yogurt sprayed with orange juice and strawberry seeds.
Spooky Grimmother hushes me as she floats closer to me and cups my face like she’s done so many times before.
The blood and brain matter doesn’t bother her.
You did it, my little numbskull. You got what you wanted.
Our foreheads touch as she chuckles.
Now, let’s take you home.
As her lips touch the space between my eyes, all I can see is a warm, bright light. And then everything goes black.

A few hours later, as the tenants of the Woodsboro Apartment rise from their beds and open their doors to go out into the world, the few who call Akilla a neighbor see her door creaking as the morning breeze travels into her apartment and carries the scent of blood into the noses of everyone nearby.
When her neighbors finally get the courage to look into her apartment, they don’t see Akilla or Omar’s body.
No one knows  All that’s left is a potted cactus with a cap on its head from The 13th Pizza sitting in a chair.
No…
I can’t do this.
I loosen my grip and stand back.
I will not lose myself to this…urge. After all of this I do want one thing to remain the same.
I want to be Omar.
I take a deep breath, as I listen to the muted ramblings of a woman I’d spent the last three days hunting down.
All that time and all that effort just to let it all go. It doesn’t make sense, but at the same time I don’t feel any regret. I do my best to make a smile.
This is good.

Good? What’s good? You’re not making any sense? Talking about something is good? The only thing good is how you’re still going to give me a refund! Talking about something good… You should be talking about the greater good!
Whatever you say, Akilla. I’d say this whole wild goose chase was fun, but you’re the worst person I’ve ever met in both of my lives so I’m just going to leave.
I turn my back and chuck up a deuce.
Omar out!
Hey, get back here! What about my refund!? I deserve a refund! I deserve your respect! I’m gonna call your manager! Get back here!

I could still hear her voice while I was driving out of Woodsboro Apartments. I hoped that it would be the last time with a little bit of luck and a lot of me begging Iggy to not have me deliver pizzas to her apartment anymore.

I stumble through the doors of The 13th Pizza and plop into a chair. I see Iggy and Ms. Gin out of the corners of my ears. Their voices are melding together with the humming of the A/C overhead, but two sounds break through it all.
Nice self-control, kiddo.
My eyes blink back the foggy haze in my vision as Spooky Grimmother becomes clearer. A yawn finds its way out of my mouth before my voice does.
Oh hey, SG. I wasn’t expecting myself to go this route either, but I’m feeling pretty good about it, you know?
Also, can Iggy and Ms. Gin see you?
She shakes her head and floats over to me so we’re face to face.
Nah, but they’ll probably see some of my coworkers once they’re on their deathbeds. Speaking of which, it’s time to move on, hun.
I chuckle until my eyes get heavy. I’m not sure if it’s exhaustion or happiness, and I’m pretty sure neither is Spooky Grimmother.
Heh… Okay. I’m ready.
For one last time, Spooky Grimmother blows a puff of skulled shaped smoke into my face and the world around me fades like wind dispersing a fog.
Hey Omar! We got another delivery coming atcha--
Iggy’s eyebrows furrow.
Omar?
Iggy stares, and Ms. Gin looks around to no avail.
In The 13th Pizza sits a cactus where I once was. No body, no soul, no Omar.
Nobody will ever know what happened to Omar.
I can’t fight it much longer.
Spooky Grimmother’s words echo in my brain.
You’re about halfway between a regular human and a brain-crazed cannibalistic corpse, and the only thing keeping you from going full zombie is your body.

My jaw goes slack as my body convulses and shakes. Soon I'm no longer staring down at the sidewalk but at the back of my own head. My body lets out a guttural groan and shambles away into the night, drooling as palm-sized sections of skin drop to the ground.
Is this it? This is how I go out? This is how the apocalypse starts?
I’m sorry kid…
